claim: Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was a founding participant of the UN.

supporting.text: The Ukrainian SSR was part of the Soviet Union, which was a founding member of the UN in 1945.

attacks.text: The Ukrainian SSR was part of the Soviet Union, which was a founding member of the UN in 1945.
The Ukrainian SSR was not a sovereign state and thus could not be a founding member of the UN.
The Soviet Union's membership did not extend to its constituent republics as independent entities.
The UN Charter explicitly required sovereign states as founding members, which the Ukrainian SSR was not.
Sovereignty is not strictly required for UN membership; non-sovereign entities can participate under certain conditions.
The Soviet Union's delegation at the UN included representatives from all its republics, effectively granting them indirect participation.
Historical precedent shows that non-sovereign territories could hold observer status or limited roles in international organizations.
The claim about sovereignty being mandatory is contradicted by cases where non-state entities were granted limited UN roles.
The Soviet Union's structure allowed its republics to act as de facto representatives in international forums like the UN.
The UN Charter does not explicitly exclude non-sovereign entities from participation in specific capacities.

supporting.text: Soviet republics like Ukraine did not have independent statehood and thus could not be separate participants in international organizations.

attacks.text: Soviet republics like Ukraine did not have independent statehood and thus could not be separate participants in international organizations.
The Ukrainian SSR held de jure representation in the UN through its inclusion as a founding member of the USSR, which acted on its behalf.
International organizations often recognize sub-state entities as participating units under specific legal frameworks, even without full independence.
Historical records confirm Ukraine's direct involvement in UN founding negotiations as a Soviet republic, contradicting claims of non-participation.
The USSR's unified sovereignty negated any possibility of sub-state entities having independent UN participation rights.
The legal distinction between 'independent statehood' and 'participation rights' in international organizations remains unresolved.
UN archives show Soviet republics were never granted individual voting rights or formal membership status in their own name.
The concept of 'unified sovereignty' is outdated; modern international law permits federated entities greater autonomy in global forums.
Participation rights in international organizations depend on recognition by member states, not solely on formal independence.
The UN Charter explicitly states that only sovereign states may join, and Soviet republics lacked such status at inception.

supporting.text: The UN Charter explicitly lists the Soviet Union as one of the original 51 members, not its constituent republics.

attacks.text: The UN Charter explicitly lists the Soviet Union as one of the original 51 members, not its constituent republics.
The Ukrainian SSR held de jure sovereignty during World War II and was admitted to international organizations independently.
Historical archives show Ukraine’s delegation participated in early UN General Assembly sessions under its own name.
The Soviet Union’s official admission encompassed all republics collectively; de jure sovereignty claims lack verifiable documentation.
UN General Assembly records from 1945 confirm only the Soviet Union’s delegation attended sessions under its unified flag.
The absence of formal recognition documents undermines claims about Ukraine’s independent wartime participation.
Archival evidence from 1945 explicitly states all delegations represented Soviet Union entities collectively.

supporting.text: Historical records show that Ukraine's participation in the UN began after it gained independence in 1991, not during its time as a Soviet republic.

attacks.text: Historical records show that Ukraine's participation in the UN began after it gained independence in 1991, not during its time as a Soviet republic.
Ukraine was part of the USSR, which was a founding member of the UN in 1945; thus, its inclusion within the USSR implies indirect participation.
The Ukrainian SSR held representation under the USSR delegation at the UN before 1991; this constitutes de facto participation in its own right.
The USSR's membership does not grant constituent republics independent UN status; each republic lacked sovereign representation at the time.
The Ukrainian SSR’s role within the USSR was administrative rather than sovereign; its UN involvement cannot be equated to independent participation.
The concept of de facto participation is legally undefined in UN membership criteria; only sovereign states are recognized as founding members.
Administrative representation does not satisfy UN Charter requirements for state sovereignty and independent voting rights at inception.

supporting.text: The Ukrainian SSR lacked diplomatic sovereignty and could not independently join international institutions like the UN.

attacks.text: The Ukrainian SSR lacked diplomatic sovereignty and could not independently join international institutions like the UN.
The Ukrainian SSR was represented by the Soviet Union in international institutions, including the UN, as it was a constituent republic.
Historical records show that the Ukrainian SSR participated in UN conferences and was recognized as a state entity during the USSR's membership.
Constituent republics of the USSR could not act independently in international affairs; their actions were controlled by the central government.
Participation in UN conferences does not equate to founding membership; the Ukrainian SSR's role was symbolic and not sovereign.

While constituent republics were part of the USSR, their inclusion in UN activities was through the USSR's official representation, which doesn't negate their participation as part of the Soviet state.
Symbolic participation does not imply sovereign membership; founding participants must have independent diplomatic status.
